discussion.content:
Selected Answer: CD
C and D

https://help.webex.com/en-us/article/n0xb944/Configure-trunks,-route-groups,-and-dial-plans-for-Webex-Calling

questions.question_text: Which two types of trunks can be used when configuring a hybrid Local Gateway for Cisco Webex Calling? (Choose two.)

choices.B: Audio bandwidth and Transcoder requirement for all calls between endpoints in different locations.
choices.C: Immersive video bandwidth and RSVP requirement for all calls between endpoints in different locations.
choices.D: Video Resolution and DSCP settings for all calls between endpoints within the same location.
choices.A: Automated Alternate Routing CSS for rerouting calls extending the configured bandwidth to a different location.
choices.E: Audio and video bandwidth for all calls between endpoints within the same location.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AE
First we most understand the difference between video and inmersive. Video is of these devices as desktop endpoints or standard video endpoints such as ip phones and softphones. Inmersive are for High definition endpoints, as Telepresence devices. Also, RSVP-based CAC and Location-based CAC are two different things.
Then:
B. is incorrect. The correct stuff would be "codecs", no "transcoders".
C. is incorrect. Immersive video does not make for all of the endpoints, rather just to telepresence endpoints, not desktop or softphone endpoints. Also, RSVP does not make to Location-based CAC (Topology-unaware CAC), rather a RSVP-based CAC (Topology-aware CAC); they are two different mechanism.
D. is incorrect, Resolution does not make to bandwith consumption. MP4 could have better resolution than MP3, even though MP4 can consume less bandwidth for better compression algorithms, so resolutions does not make to CAC.

comments.content:
and Finally:
A. is correct, the AAR feature enables CUCM to establish an alternate path for the voice media when the preferred path (IP) between two intracluster endpoints runs out of available bandwidth, as determined by the locations mechanism for CAC.
E. is correct.- Location-based CAC works with the maximum audio/video bandwidth allowed into and out of a location, that is all, no anything else more.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: CE
The location configuration itself consists of three main parts: links, intra-location bandwidth parameters, and RSVP locations settings. The RSVP locations settings are not considered here for Enhanced Location CAC because they apply only to RSVP implementations. In the configuration, the link bandwidth parameters are displayed first while the intra-location bandwidth parameters are hidden and displayed by selecting the Show advanced link.

The intra-location bandwidth parameters allow the administrator to configure bandwidth allocations for three call types: audio, video, and immersive. 
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/voice_ip_comm/cucm/srnd/collab11/collab11/cac.html#68030

Selected Answer: AC
Please refer to the definition of Audio/Video bandwidth using link below:

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/voice_ip_comm/cucm/admin/10_0_1/ccmcfg/CUCM_BK_C95ABA82_00_admin-guide-100/CUCM_BK_C95ABA82_00_admin-guide-100_chapter_010000.html#CUCM_RF_A68AFDC6_00

"Audio Bandwidth: Enter the maximum amount of audio bandwidth (in kb/s) that is available for all audio calls on the link between this location and other locations"

Key word here is "between this location and other locations", so it is not E..it is A and C

Selected Answer: AC
Definitely A, but I think C is the other correct option.

CAC doesn't specific transcoder requirements, so not B. CAC is not used to specify video resolution or DSCP settings, so no D. And E is not correct as the whole purpose of CAC is to specify bandwidth settings BETWEEN different locations, not within the same location, so not E.

There is a section in the Location configuration for "RSVP Setting" (it's a dropdown), and a radio bubble that allows you to specify session bandwidth for video calls and immersive video calls for calls between locations. C checks out.

Selected Answer: AE
For me it is A and E.
AAR is part of Location based CAC 

https://www.globalknowledge.com/us-en/resources/resource-library/articles/call-admission-control/#gref 

E is the essential of configuring locations, what do I miss?

Transcoder requirements are not part of CAC. 

RSVP is also not part of CAC, it could be an additional method to achieve call admission control (CAC) besides location-based CAC 

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/voice_ip_comm/cucm/admin/10_0_1/ccmsys/CUCM_BK_SE5FCFB6_00_cucm-system-guide-100/CUCM_BK_SE5FCFB6_00_cucm-system-guide-100_chapter_01001.html

questions.question_text: Which two configurations are needed for Cisco UCM location-based CAC? (Choose two.)

choices.E: Set the call forward all CSS to restrict international patterns.
choices.C: Set the service parameter to block off-net to off-net transfers.
choices.D: Restrict international patterns on SIP trunk CSS to the gateway.
choices.A: Implement a class of restrictions on the gateway.
choices.B: Implement transformation pattern for all off-net calls.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: CE
C and E are correct.
C, E. CFA should not be set/allow to international. Disable offNet to offNet explains it self.

questions.question_text: A recent audit discovered incidents of toll fraud. Restrictions should include Cisco UCM class of service and supplementary services features. Which two actions in Cisco UCM prevent further toll fraud from happening? (Choose two.)

choices.D: Reset the phone being called in Cisco UCM.
choices.B: Restart the Cisco CallManager service on all nodes.
choices.C: Reset the destination SIP trunk in Cisco UCM.
choices.A: Check the calling privileges of the line and device.

comments.content:
It is impossible to define if to reset a phone or a trunk if there is not enough information about the client what type of device is, but the server is a CUCM11.5. The only thing is that there was an INVITE from the device client, and the CUCM answered with a 404. So, What am I going to reset if I don't know what device is on the other side of the CUCM?
D. is incorrect, the called device is not a phone, it is rather a PSTN number.
C. it is a call to a international call to a PSTN.
If it is a international call, also it is a CSS that blocks international calls, this is another reason than the answer could be A.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
I see the exhibit is a wireshark capture that could be gather in any point of the nework. SOurce port is 5060, from a Cisco-CUCM11.5 server to a dest port 49381 that is owned by a device with a DN 1000. The domain is the same in From: and To: Headers. Now, the device is not said if is a trunk or a phone. By the number, it seems to be a Phone, however, in the From: header there is not the type of device, perhaps a third party device. In these conditions, I think that correct answer is A, check first the calling privileges of the line and device.
A because line CSS it has problem

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. Which troubleshooting step must be performed to investigate the issue?

discussion.content: Sorry A is the correct answer: DSCP for Audio Portion of Video Calls

comments.content:
Yes, A is the correct answer. 

The DSCP for Audio Calls setting is used for any device that makes an audio-only call. The DSCP for Video Calls setting is used for the audio and video traffic of any device that is classified as "desktop." DSCP for TelePresence Calls is used for the audio and video traffic of any device that is classified as "immersive." The DSCP for Audio Portion of Video Calls and DSCP for Audio Portion of TelePresence Calls are currently applicable to a subset of video endpoints and differentiate only the audio portion of video calls dependent on the video call type based on classification. See the section on Trusted Endpoints, for more information.

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/voice_ip_comm/cucm/srnd/collab11/collab11/cac.html

discussion.content:
The correct answer should be B. There is no such parameter "DSCP for Audio Portion of CISCO TelePresence Calls", it is called DSCP for Audio Portion of TelePresence Calls. Therefore B is correct:
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/voice_ip_comm/cucm/admin/12_0_1/systemConfig/cucm_b_system-configuration-guide-1201/cucm_b_system-configuration-guide-1201_chapter_01000001.html

This section of service parameters includes clusterwide DSCP values for a wide range of audio and video call types, including DSCP for audio calls, video calls, the audio portion of a video call, TelePresence calls, and the audio portion of a TelePresence call.

It is highly recommended that you keep these parameters set to the default value unless a Cisco support engineer instructs otherwise.

Selected Answer: C

choices.A: DSCP for audio portion of video calls
choices.C: DSCP for audio portion of Cisco Telepresence calls
